discourse_list.title: Why are there DAI borrowers using Ether as collateral?

content.content: Why are there people minting DAI using Eth as collateral if they could borrow DAI with a lower collateralisation ratio (and much the same APY) on a platform like Aave? On oasis borrow The stability fee is 3.5% (I assume that’s an APY) and the Min. Coll. Ratio is 150%:  image756×448 39.7 KB  On Aave: The variable APY is 3.6% and the Liquidation Threshold is 80% (corresponds to a Min. Coll. Ratio of 125%):  image1570×778 90 KB
content.GPT-summary: The post is asking a question about why people are using Ether as collateral to mint DAI instead of borrowing DAI with a lower collateralization ratio on platforms like Aave. The post provides a comparison of the stability fee and minimum collateralization ratio on Oasis Borrow and Aave.

content.content: Less liquidation penalty Some clients require very large positions and doing so on Aave would actually change the rates

I was recently told that AAVE and COMPOUND is perfect for those who do not have the necessary quota to open a vault. Also a positive point is that regardless of whether or not you open positions in AAVE you continue to earn interest on the asset you put up as collateral.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving positive feedback on proposal

content.content: Thanks, could you clarify your second point here?
at AAVE when you deposit collateral you immediately start earning interest, whether you borrow or not. That makes it very positive.
Got it, thanks. I guess the deposit APY on ETH on Aave is 0.05% so I’m not sure that would be a big factor. Unless I’m missing something there?
is in ETH bro, ETH to THE MOON
Some users just borrow one day, buy a tesla and come back 2 years later to pay back they loan. They don’t manage they loan on a day to day basis.

So your point there is that this type of user is not very discerning on prices. Still, one would have to imagine there are discerning actors on the platform and that - if they feel prices are better on Aave than Maker - they would just use Aave. The best arguments I see so far for using Maker (despite needing more collateral) are:  Maker allows for larger positions without moving rates (because rates are set by governance). Less liquidation penalty (although I would imagine this is fully or more than offset by the higher collateral required on Maker).

There are few strong advantages of borrowing at Maker vs Aave/Compound etc, especially for positions of much larger proportions;  Price of debt at Maker is always 1; you won’t get liquidated if price of borrowed stablecoin trades with a premium OSM price delay of 1h; you have time to react before you are liquidated when collateral prices are falling Stable interest rate for the time period; interest rate in Maker is changed with an executive vote, therefore users have some period of fixed rates. Additionally, interest rates are not dependent on market utilization, which is unpredictable for everyone and larger users need to be very careful as they will definitely impact the rate  In my view, Aave and Compound are unique in that you can short sell, or earn interest on your assets by just supplying them.
